articles.headline: Americans Are Finally Saving. How Did That Happen?
articles.snippet: The American savings rate hit a 16-year high in the spring, and the reasons went beyond the poor economy. Tighter credit and retirement accounts played a part.
articles.abstract: The American savings rate hit a 16-year high in the spring, and the reasons went beyond the poor economy. Tighter credit and retirement accounts played a part.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was the year of the return to financial sobriety  if you judge such things by the nation’s personal savings rate.

articles.headline: Nice Gift, but Ask if You Can Return It
articles.snippet: Many stores have changed their rules regarding returns and exchanges since last year’s holiday shopping season, meaning consumers need to be more diligent.
articles.abstract: Many stores have changed their rules regarding returns and exchanges since last year’s holiday shopping season, meaning consumers need to be more diligent.
articles.lead_paragraph: So you think you’ve picked out the perfect gift for your loved one. But there’s one more thing you should consider: how hard will it be to return it?

articles.headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Trims Losses by Making a Hamster Hot
articles.snippet: Toys “R” Us is identifying and promoting the next hot toy as part of a new commitment to service and supply that is helping it achieve a turnaround.
articles.abstract: Toys “R” Us is identifying and promoting the next hot toy as part of a new commitment to service and supply that is helping it achieve a turnaround.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long before stockings were hung and Christmas trees twinkled in windows, the chief of Toys “R” Us threw his company’s weight behind an odd bet.

articles.headline: Cancer Center Ads Use Emotion More Than Fact
articles.snippet: Advertisements for cancer centers can get away with statements that would be off-limits to drug makers.
articles.abstract: Advertisements for cancer centers can get away with statements that would be off-limits to drug makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A print advertisement for prostate cancer surgery at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan is typical of the way many elite research and teaching hospitals sell hope to the public.

articles.headline: G.I.’s in Iraq Hope to Heal Sacred Walls
articles.snippet: The United States Army hopes to restore St. Elijah’s Monastery, an ancient site of Christian worship stuck in the middle of a base in northern Iraq.
articles.abstract: The United States Army hopes to restore St. Elijah’s Monastery, an ancient site of Christian worship stuck in the middle of a base in northern Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORWARD OPERATING BASE MAREZ, Iraq  When the 101st Airborne Division captured this base back in 2003, an American tank blasted the turret off a T-72 tank, catapulting it into the side of St. Elijah’s Monastery.

articles.headline: A Lament for Saab, Quirky but Loved
articles.snippet: Auto enthusiasts across the U.S. were dismayed that G.M. was planning to close Saab, a maker of quirky but revered cars.
articles.abstract: Auto enthusiasts across the U.S. were dismayed that G.M. was planning to close Saab, a maker of quirky but revered cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ignition was in the floor. It had a rear hatchback, not a trunk. The hood was hinged at the front, so it opened away from the windshield. And many of its owners  including Jerry Seinfeld’s character on his long-running sitcom  were intensely loyal.

articles.headline: Executive at Barclays Defends Pay
articles.snippet: Robert E. Diamond Jr. said that high performance, not greed, was behind his big paydays.
articles.abstract: Robert E. Diamond Jr. said that high performance, not greed, was behind his big paydays.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  “If you really love working for Barclays, why do you need that huge incentive to do the job you are paid to do anyway?”

articles.headline: Afghan Killing Bares a Karzai Family Feud
articles.snippet: A youth’s murder has set off bitter divisions among President Hamid Karzai’s relatives in Afghanistan and the U.S., with charges of a cover-up by Afghan officials.
articles.abstract: A youth’s murder has set off bitter divisions among President Hamid Karzai’s relatives in Afghanistan and the U.S., with charges of a cover-up by Afghan officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  On Oct. 16, four sport utility vehicles barreled into Karz, Afghanistan, the hometown of the country’s president, Hamid Karzai, and pulled up to the home of one of his cousins, Yar Mohammad Karzai.

articles.headline: A Reader’s Digest That Grandma Never Dreamed Of
articles.snippet: Battered by billions of dollars in debt, the magazine empire known for folksy charm is becoming less folksy (and trying to keep its charm).
articles.abstract: Battered by billions of dollars in debt, the magazine empire known for folksy charm is becoming less folksy (and trying to keep its charm).
articles.lead_paragraph: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

articles.headline: My Initiation at Store 5476
articles.snippet: A reporter takes on a holiday challenge: what it’s like to be one worker in the army it takes to run a Wal-Mart store in New Jersey.
articles.abstract: A reporter takes on a holiday challenge: what it’s like to be one worker in the army it takes to run a Wal-Mart store in New Jersey.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEPTFORD, N.J.

articles.headline: Justices Revisit Rule Requiring Lab Testimony
articles.snippet: Prosecutors argue that mandatory court appearances keep crime analysts away from their laboratory work.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors argue that mandatory court appearances keep crime analysts away from their laboratory work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Virginia Hernandez Lopez admitted to knocking back two shots of tequila with Sprite chasers on an August night in Julian, Calif., a couple of years ago. But she said she was not drunk when her Ford Explorer collided with an oncoming Toyota pickup truck later that night, killing its driver.

articles.headline: Mercer’s Little Alaska Problem
articles.snippet: A suit seeking $2.8 billion in damages from Mercer, the human resources consultant, could have longer consequences for actuarial firms.
articles.abstract: A suit seeking $2.8 billion in damages from Mercer, the human resources consultant, could have longer consequences for actuarial firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH it has received little coverage lately, a bombshell of a lawsuit inching its way through the superior court of Alaska has revealed the financial strain visited on state workers there and promises to have ramifications for public pensions across the country.

articles.headline: Compromising on 2 Issues, Obama Gets Partial Wins
articles.snippet: From Copenhagen to Capitol Hill, the president determined the outer limits of what he could accomplish on climate change and health care and decided that was enough, for now.
articles.abstract: From Copenhagen to Capitol Hill, the president determined the outer limits of what he could accomplish on climate change and health care and decided that was enough, for now.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, likes to say that the only thing that is not negotiable is success. The last 48 hours offered a case study in how the president applies that maxim to governing.

articles.headline: China’s Export of Labor Faces Scorn
articles.snippet: China is increasingly known for shipping out cheap labor, and a backlash against Chinese workers has grown in Africa and Asia.
articles.abstract: China is increasingly known for shipping out cheap labor, and a backlash against Chinese workers has grown in Africa and Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRUNG SON, Vietnam  It seemed as if this village in northern Vietnam had struck gold when a Chinese and a Japanese company arrived to jointly build a coal-fired power plant. Thousands of jobs would start flowing in, or so the residents hoped.

articles.headline: For Saab, Still a Shot at Survival
articles.snippet: A tiny Dutch automaker that sells 50 cars a year is trying to save the Swedish brand, but G.M. is said to have qualms.
articles.abstract: A tiny Dutch automaker that sells 50 cars a year is trying to save the Swedish brand, but G.M. is said to have qualms.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Could Saab yet be saved?

articles.headline: New Programs Aim to Lure Young Into Digital Jobs
articles.snippet: The country needs more cool nerds — people who can use computing in ways that haven’t even been thought of yet. High schools are starting to do their part.
articles.abstract: The country needs more cool nerds — people who can use computing in ways that haven’t even been thought of yet. High schools are starting to do their part.
articles.lead_paragraph: Growing up in the ’70s, John Halamka was a bookish child with a penchant for science and electronics. He wore black horn-rimmed glasses and buttoned his shirts up to the collar.

articles.headline: After a Year of Ruin, Some Hope
articles.snippet: With a little bit of luck, maybe the media industry can conjure itself as a new kind of workplace that doesn’t include the legacy costs of trucks and printing presses.
articles.abstract: With a little bit of luck, maybe the media industry can conjure itself as a new kind of workplace that doesn’t include the legacy costs of trucks and printing presses.
articles.lead_paragraph: The current state of the media reminds me of the time I was taking down the rigging on my pal’s catamaran with my friend Ed. While I busied myself with the main sail, Ed, who was not much of a sailor, went to take down the small sail in the front of the boat. Instead, he pulled the pin that kept the mast standing, and everything  a mass of steel, rope and canvas  came crashing down around us.

articles.headline: Labor Data Show Surge in Hiring of Temp Workers
articles.snippet: Employers might soon take the next step of bringing on permanent workers if recovery seems durable.
articles.abstract: Employers might soon take the next step of bringing on permanent workers if recovery seems durable.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hiring of temporary workers has surged, suggesting that the nation’s employers might soon take the next step, bringing on permanent workers, if they can just convince themselves that the upturn in the economy will be sustained.

articles.headline: In a Distressed Year, Hollywood Smiles
articles.snippet: Premium-price tickets will help the industry reach more than $10 billion in ticket sales by the end of 2009.
articles.abstract: Premium-price tickets will help the industry reach more than $10 billion in ticket sales by the end of 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  This was the year that Hollywood hit the jackpot by informing us that Mike Tyson keeps a pet tiger, Spock had a fling with Uhura, Hogwarts School needs a new head, the world will end in 2012, and even George Clooney is up in the air when it comes to women.

articles.headline: Storm on Big Weekend Raises Worries for Stores
articles.snippet: A storm gave consumers a reason to stay at home on what is normally a blockbuster weekend for retailers.
articles.abstract: A storm gave consumers a reason to stay at home on what is normally a blockbuster weekend for retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a year of recession and uncertainty, the last thing retailers needed was a blizzard to hit the weekend before Christmas.

articles.headline: Civilians Train in ‘Afghan City’ in the Midwest
articles.snippet: Some Americans are being trained for a “civilian surge,” a campaign intended to improve the lives of Afghans.
articles.abstract: Some Americans are being trained for a “civilian surge,” a campaign intended to improve the lives of Afghans.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUTLERVILLE, Ind.  For American civilians serving in Afghanistan, the last stop before they ship out to Kabul or Kandahar is a dilapidated, vaguely foreboding institution that once served as a farm colony for “feeble-minded” boys, and later was a state mental hospital.

articles.headline: Records Fall as Snow Blankets East Coast
articles.snippet: Eastern Long Island and parts of Virginia got two feet of snow, and records were set in Washington and Baltimore.
articles.abstract: Eastern Long Island and parts of Virginia got two feet of snow, and records were set in Washington and Baltimore.
articles.lead_paragraph: It came up the coast on the last weekend of autumn, a ghostly apparition of midwinter, roaring into the solitude of cities and countrysides from the Carolinas to Cape Cod with blizzardlike ferocity. It closed airports, roads and malls and recreated Whittier’s snowbound American landscape for 60 million people.

articles.headline: Cleric’s Funeral Becomes Protest of Iran Leaders
articles.snippet: Mourners for a founding father of Iran’s Islamic revolution flooded the holy city of Qum and faced off with Iranian security forces, witnesses said.
articles.abstract: Mourners for a founding father of Iran’s Islamic revolution flooded the holy city of Qum and faced off with Iranian security forces, witnesses said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The funeral of a prominent dissident cleric in the holy Iranian city of Qum turned into a huge and furious antigovernment rally on Monday, raising the possibility that the cleric’s death could serve as a catalyst for an opposition movement that has been locked in a stalemate with the authorities.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Nazila Fathi
